pros:
Same as all UT schools the state benefits are good: free insurance, TRS retirement, 11 holidays (including the week off for Christmas), good PTO that accumulates faster based on prior state service.
Affordable gym membership (about the same cost as planet fitness)
cons:
Everything is so slow moving yet demands are sometimes high. Other departments like IT and EHS hold up things that need to get done. Not enough resources to get jobs done.
Lack of vision, it seems like leadership changes frequently and there is no long-term plan. The junior college honestly seems better positioned for the future than UT. New buildings are great but it takes more than that to improve enrollment.
But maybe the worst thing is how unbalanced the pay is; low level employees like TAs and non-tenure track make very little while upper management makes ridiculous money. Typical for every rung up the ladder to make double the money of their subordinates and the organization is very top heavy because of it. Higher ups are making what the big schools in Austin and Arlington make.

pros: Very healthy environment to work.
cons: Lack of research resources for the work as undergraduate.

review_title: Sick campus culture inhibits the innovation that is theoretically encouraged.
pros: Employees tend to have a lot of autonomy in their day to day work. The campus is beautiful. Health benefits are very good. The administration has recently been responsive to issues of salary stagnation. As the campus grows, there are many opportunities to implement new technologies and pedagogies. The campus offers a good variety of amenities and entertainment for a school of this size. Support departments are very competent. Staff/faculty research is generally encouraged and celebrated.
cons: HR and leadership go to great lengths not to deal with interpersonal issues (including harassment, bullying, chronic communication failures). The administration rarely consults campus stakeholders in making major decisions; the administration is not transparent about funding decisions. Leadership roles and hierarchies change constantly. Major divisions exist between upper management and the rest of the campus. Within the campus community, divisions are just as stark (professionals v. paraprofessionals, tenured v. non-tenured faculty, faculty v. professionals, departments against other departments). Paraprofessional contributions to the campus are not valued; paraprofessionals receive little or no funding for professional development. It is a combative environment at every level. Gossip and rumor-mongering abound; it is not uncommon to hear individuals openly speak about their desire to undermine other individuals or departments. Merit is not a predictor of success or advancement,.

pros: Great benefits. Flexible hours. Wonderful students.
cons: Upper management does not care about what the faculty thinks about anything.

job_title: Assistant Professor of Psychology in Tyler, TX
pros: No culture of high-pressure grant activity or working 60hrs/wk, dual career hires are common, students are very eager to learn and appreciative, advising is done by staff and specialized (not centralized), institution is becoming more supportive of research, people are generally collegial
cons: Department budgets got partially taken over by the provost, disrupting start-up funding to faculty. Department chairs have to beg for money they've already allocated for such things. HR is a mess (high turnover, tend to screw up FMLA for staff, multiple faculty have been "autoterminated" at the beginning of the summer and not paid on time) structurally it's not friendly to international workers despite talking about valuing diversity (visa applications done dangerously late, discourage from hiring people who need visa sponsorship); faculty also do not reflect domestic diversity of the area and student body; faculty lines from deceased or retired faculty may disappear instead of being replaced; department faculty are chronically understaffed and class sizes for lecturers are ridiculous; check current news stories for other concerns

job_title: Student IT Analyst in Buda, TX
pros:
Laid back atmosphere, able to work on challenging projects if you're looking for complexity, or maintain low ticket numbers while working on homework or another projects.

Full-time staff is very helpful and always willing to explain issues if you're interested. Lots of support from everyone in the office.
cons: No major cons here. If anything, working in CCS can get boring at times when there aren't a lot of tickets, but fewer issues is the goal when working support. Having some projects to work on in the downtime might have been nice.

review_title: I worked as a Mathematics and Physics Tutor

cons: Sometimes the HR department would delay the pay checks because of technical issues and I would have trouble managing my finances (since I am a college student as well).

pros: Management will sometimes listen to good ideas, very open to different walks of life.  There are a number of international students hired.  The work stays at work, as per upper management.
cons: There is a high turnover rate given that it is a student worker job, so you will have people who may not care about the rest of the department who are hired.  International students do not always have the greatest grasp of English.
